sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Two closely related genera,Campylobacter and Sulfurospirillum, are currently included in the family Campylobacteraceae (1–3). The family Campylobacteraceae includes 53 species in the genus Campylobacter and 8 species in the genus Sulfurospirillum (4). Arcobacter, previously included in the family Campylobacteraceae, is now classified as the sole species in its own family, Arcobacteraceae (3, 5), with 33 species in the genus, although recently, a proposal to split the family into several new genera has received considerable controversy (1, 6, 7). As such, only the genus name Arcobacter is used for this chapter. Since the last edition of this Manual, descriptions of several new species and subspecies of Campylobacter and Arcobacter have been published, and they are described below.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
sect2.para: Campylobacter spp. are curved, S-shaped, or spiral rods that are 0.2 to 0.9 μm wide and 0.5 to 5 μm long. A few species, such as Campylobacter hominis, form straight rods. Campylobacter species are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming rods that may form spherical or coccoid bodies in old cultures or cultures exposed to air for prolonged periods. Organisms are usually motile by means of a single polar unsheathed flagellum at one or both ends, but some may lack flagella. Species are generally microaerobic with a respiratory type of metabolism, but some strains grow aerobically, while others grow anaerobically. An atmosphere containing increased hydrogen (5 to 7%) is required by some species for microaerobic growth (8). Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni, C. coli, C. upsaliensis, and C. fetus subsp. fetus are the species most commonly isolated in the clinical laboratory.

Arcobacter spp. are Gram-negative, slightly curved, curved, S-shaped, or helical non-spore-forming rods that are 0.2 to 0.9 μm wide and 1 to 3 μm long. Organisms are usually motile with a single polar unsheathed flagellum. Arcobacter anaerophilus is nonmotile (9). Arcobacter spp. grow microaerobically at 15°C, 25°C, and 30°C, have variable growth at 37°C and 42°C, and do not require increased hydrogen for growth. Arcobacter spp. may grow aerobically at 30°C and anaerobically at 35°C to 37°C. Most strains are nonhemolytic. Arcobacter skirrowii may be alpha-hemolytic (10). Arcobacter halophilus is an obligate halophile and grows poorly on media containing less than 2% NaCl (10). Arcobacter butzleri and A. cryaerophilus are the two clinically relevant species isolated in the clinical laboratory.

Originally classified as free-livingCampylobacter species, Sulfurospirillum spp. are slender, curved Gram-negative rods, 0.1 to 0.5 μm wide and 1 to 3 μm long. All of the species are sulfur reducers and exhibit variable metabolic activity. Sulfurospirillum deleyianum is the type species of the genus (11). These species have no known pathogenicity for humans or animals and are environmental organisms isolated from water sediments (2).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Campylobacter species are primarily zoonotic, with a variety of animals implicated as reservoirs for human infection (Table 1). In addition to being present in food animals, such as poultry, cattle, sheep, and pigs, Campylobacter species may be present in domestic pets. Humans appear to be the only recognized reservoirs for the periodontal-disease-related species C. concisus, C. rectus, C. curvus, and C. showae.

Campylobacter infections are common in both developed and developing countries. The reported incidence of culture-confirmed infections varies considerably from country to country, and as culturing practices and reporting requirements can vary, direct comparison of the reported incidences can be complex. In the United States, where reporting practices vary from state to state, the Foodborne Diseases Active Surveillance Program, or FoodNet (www.cdc.gov/foodnet), provides uniform reporting from a panel of sentinel sites, giving an accurate incidence of laboratory-confirmed infections. From 2016 to 2019, the highest incidence of infections tracked by FoodNet was that of Campylobacter infections, with an overall incidence of 19.5/100,000 population. Compared with 2016 to 2018, the incidence of Campylobacter infections in 2019 increased 13% (12). There are some concerns in the public health sector about the effect of culture-independent diagnostic tests on disease reporting and incidence rates, although the effect on measured disease incidence is not understood at this time (13). Additional concerns about using culture-independent diagnostic tests include the lack of isolates for epidemiologic typing and antimicrobial susceptibility testing (14).

C. jejuni subsp. jejuni (referred to as C. jejuni) continues to be the most common enteric pathogen isolated from patients, as reported from some states in FoodNet, with 1.3 million cases estimated in the United States annually (15, 16). Because of underdiagnosis and underreporting, the actual incidence in any country is substantially greater than the reported incidence. In the United States, although the incidence of campylobacteriosis has changed, the epidemiology is otherwise unchanged (17). Campylobacter infections are usually sporadic; the incidence starts to rise in March, with a peak in the summer, and declines in early fall (17). Infection usually follows ingestion of improperly handled or cooked food, primarily poultry products. Case-control studies in both the United States and Europe continue to find eating poultry to be a significant risk factor for developing campylobacteriosis (17).

Approximately one-half of the outbreaks in the United States from 1998 to 2004 were associated with dairy products or water; the remaining outbreaks were mostly foodborne, and 44% were attributed to poultry (17). From 1998 to 2002, there were 64 foodborne Campylobacter outbreaks causing 1,628 illnesses, compared to 92 outbreaks and 1,431 illnesses during 2003 to 2007. Foodborne disease outbreaks due to contaminated nonpasteurized milk were still common from 2007 to 2012, with 81% of milk-associated outbreaks being caused by Campylobacter (18). Outbreaks in other developed countries are also associated with food, water, or dairy product contamination (17). In developing countries, Campylobacter is often isolated from persons who may or may not have diarrheal disease. Most symptomatic infections occur in infancy and early childhood, and incidence decreases with age. Campylobacter infection is a leading cause of travel-associated gastroenteritis (19). The incidence of infection follows a bimodal age distribution, with the highest incidence in infants and young children, followed by a second peak in adults 20 to 40 years old (16). Secondary transmission of Campylobacter from ill persons to other individuals is rare, even though the infectious dose for developing illness is not particularly high and can be as low as 500 CFU (20).

sect1.title: C. jejuni and C. coli
sect1.para: C. jejuni and C. coli have been recognized since the early 1970s as agents of gastrointestinal infection. C. jejuni is one of the most common causes of bacterial enteritis in the United States. C. jejuni and C. coli continue to be the most common Campylobacter species associated with diarrheal illness and produce clinically indistinguishable infections. Most laboratories do not routinely distinguish between these organisms. In patients with gastroenteritis caused by C. jejuni/C. coli, patients’ symptoms range from mild to severe, including fever, abdominal cramping, and diarrhea (with or without blood/fecal white cells) that lasts several days to more than 1 week (21). A systematic review of the incubation period for campylobacteriosis found a mean of 2.5 to 4.3 days, depending on the subgroup examined (22). Symptomatic infections are usually self-limited, but relapses may occur in 5 to 10% of untreated patients (21).

Hospitalizations are common forCampylobacter infections, with 18% of laboratory-confirmed infections reported to FoodNet requiring hospitalization in 2018 (12, 23). Campylobacter infection may mimic acute appendicitis and result in unnecessary surgery. Extraintestinal infections following Campylobacter enteritis have been reported and include bacteremia, hepatitis, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, abortion and neonatal sepsis, nephritis, prostatitis, urinary tract infection, peritonitis, myocarditis, and focal infections, including meningitis, septic arthritis, and abscess formation (21, 24). Campylobacter bacteremia has been recognized for many years and is reported to occur at a rate of 1.5 per 1,000 intestinal infections, with the highest rate in the elderly (25). C. jejuni and C. fetus subsp fetus continue to be common species causing the majority of bacteremia cases (26). Persistent diarrheal illness and bacteremia may occur in immunocompromised hosts, such as patients with human immunodeficiency virus infection, and may be difficult to treat (21). Deaths attributable to C. jejuni infection are uncommon (21). The health burden of campylobacteriosis appears to be substantial and may be underrecognized (27).

C.jejuni is the most often recognized infection preceding the development of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), an acute paralytic disease of the peripheral nervous system. Certain heat-stable (HS) serotypes appear to be overrepresented in GBS cases, such as HS:19 and HS:41, but other more common serotypes are frequently reported (28). The pathogenesis of Campylobacter-induced GBS involves host immune responses to ganglioside-like epitopes present in the core region of the lipooligosaccharide (29), which in the susceptible host mediate damage to the peripheral nerves, where ganglioside targets are highly enriched (30).

Reactive arthritis sometimes followsCampylobacter infection, with pain and joint swelling lasting an average of 2 weeks, with a range of a few weeks to nearly a year. Reiter’s syndrome may also occur in some patients (21). Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is now a known sequela of campylobacter infection (31).

The pathogenesis ofCampylobacter enteric infection is still not well understood. The infective dose of Campylobacter may be as few as 500 organisms capable of causing illness (21). The use of proton pump inhibitors increases susceptibility to Campylobacter infection (32). The signs and symptoms of infection suggest an invasive mechanism of disease. A variety of determinants may be important in the virulence of C. jejuni infection, including adherence to the intestinal mucosa, bacterial effects on the cell, and host inflammatory responses (33).

sect1.title: Campylobacter Species Other Than C. jejuni and C. coli
sect1.para: Campylobacter species other than C. jejuni and C. coli are increasingly isolated from human infections by improved culture methods that are optimal for the non-C. jejuni and non-C. coli species. Only those isolated from human specimens are discussed in this section. Reservoirs of Campylobacter spp. are summarized in Table 1.

C. fetus subsp. fetus is primarily associated with bacteremia and extraintestinal infections during pregnancy or in the compromised host (26). Although gastroenteritis does occur with this species, the incidence is probably underestimated because the organism may not grow well at 42°C and is usually susceptible to cephalothin (cefalotin), an antimicrobial agent used in some common selective media for stool cultures (34). C. fetus subsp. venerealis causes bovine venereal campylobacteriosis and is a cause of bovine infertility but is rarely the cause of human infection (35). C. fetus subsp. testudinum is a new subspecies that has been isolated from humans and reptiles (lizards) and can be differentiated from C. fetus subsp. fetus and C. fetus subsp. venerealis only by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometry techniques (36, 37).

C. lari is a thermophilic species isolated from gulls and other avian species, dogs, cats, and chickens. C. lari has been infrequently isolated from humans with bacteremia and gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections (38). Phylogenetic studies have described two subspecies, C. lari subsp. concheus and C. lari subsp. lari (39). C. lari may be included in molecular multiplex detection kits for enteric pathogens.

C. upsaliensis is a thermotolerant species that causes diarrhea and bacteremia in humans and is also associated with canine and feline gastroenteritis (38). Over a 7-year period in a Belgian reference microbiology laboratory, C. upsaliensis was the most common non-C. jejuni/non-C. coli species isolated from stool samples submitted to the laboratory for culture (40). C. upsaliensis is susceptible to many antimicrobial agents present in C. jejuni-selective media and thus is usually not isolated on routine primary isolation media; it can be recovered using the filtration technique. C. upsaliensis may be included in some molecular multiplex detection kits for enteric pathogens.

OtherCampylobacter species have been isolated from clinical specimens of patients with a variety of diseases, but their pathogenic role has not been determined (38). C. jejuni subsp. doylei is a nitrate-negative subspecies of C. jejuni rarely recovered from patients with upper gastrointestinal tract infections and gastroenteritis (38). C. peloridis has been isolated from human feces, dialysis fluid, and shellfish (39). C. concisus has been isolated from both fecal and blood specimens. There are reports on the association of this species with gastrointestinal disease, but additional case-control studies are needed to establish the pathogenicity of this organism (41–43). C. curvus has been isolated from patients with periodontal infections and in patients with liver abscesses and pneumonia (44). There is some suggestion that C. curvus may be an etiologic agent in diarrheal illness (45), but it was rarely isolated from stool samples in another large study (46). C. gracilis has been isolated from patients with appendicitis/peritonitis, bacteremia, soft tissue abscesses, and pulmonary infections (47). C. hominis has been isolated from fecal samples of healthy individuals and may be a commensal of the oral cavity (48). C. hyointestinalis has been occasionally associated with proctitis and diarrhea in human infection (49). C. lanienae was isolated from two asymptomatic abattoir workers and a hospitalized patient with diarrhea and fever, but its clinical significance is unknown (50, 51). C. mucosalis was reported to have been isolated from two children with enteritis, but subsequent testing showed that the isolates were actually C. concisus (52). C. rectus is primarily isolated from patients with active periodontal infections but has also been isolated from patients with pulmonary infection (38, 53) and a breast abscess (44). C. sputorum has been associated with lung, axillary, scrotal, and groin abscesses (38). C. sputorum bv. paraureolyticus, formerly referred to as catalase-negative urease-positive campylobacter, has been isolated from patients with diarrhea, but the significance of this finding is unknown (54). C. showae has been isolated from the human gingival crevice (55) and from a blood culture in a patient with cholangitis (56). Campylobacter blaseri is most closely related to C. ureolyticus and has been isolated from harbor seals in the Netherlands, but it has yet to be described as causing human infection (57).

sect1.title: Arcobacter
sect1.para: Arcobacter spp. are aerotolerant, Campylobacter-like organisms frequently isolated from a variety of animal sources, including cattle, sheep, pigs, poultry, birds, and other sources (58, 59). Two of the 33 Arcobacter species have been associated with human infection. A. butzleri, A. cryaerophilus, and A. skirrowii were recently reclassified in the genus Aliarcobacter within the same family, Arcobacteraceae, although the studies used to propose the new genus have been challenged (6, 7). A. butzleri has been isolated from patients with bacteremia, endocarditis, peritonitis, and diarrhea and was identified, by molecular methods, as the causative agent of an outbreak of foodborne illness in Wisconsin (38, 40, 60). A. cryaerophilus was previously characterized into two DNA-related groups, 1A and 1B (61). A. cryaerophilus group 1B has been isolated from patients with bacteremia and diarrhea (38, 40) and also from healthy individuals (62), suggesting a commensal role for this species. Group 1A has been isolated from animal sources (61). A. butzleri was reported to be the fourth most common Campylobacter-like organism isolated from patients with diarrhea by Vandenberg et al. (40) and was also one of the most common non-C. jejuni/non-C. coli species isolated over a 10-year period from over 73,000 stool samples (63). Thus, A. butzleri may be underrecognized if appropriate culture conditions are not used. In a survey of 2,855 Campylobacter-like isolates submitted for characterization from laboratories in France, A. butzleri was identified in 1%, primarily from fecal samples of patients with a diarrheal illness (64). A. skirrowii was reported to be isolated from a human stool culture from a patient with chronic diarrhea, but the role of this species in human disease is unknown (65). None of the new species described since 2019 have been associated with human disease.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
Culture-Based Methods
sect2.para: Fecal specimens are preferred for isolatingCampylobacter species from older children and adult patients with gastrointestinal infections; rectal swabs are acceptable for children and infants (66, 67). For hospitalized patients, the “3-day” rule (rejection of specimens collected >72 h after admission) should be used as a criterion for acceptability of routine culture requests (68, 69). For routine purposes, a single stool sample has high sensitivity for common enteric pathogens (70, 71), but two samples may be desirable, depending upon clinical or preanalytic circumstances, such as a >2-h delay in transport of the first sample, which could affect recovery. A transport medium such as Cary-Blair, Fecal Enteric Plus, or the equivalent should be used when a delay of more than 2 h is anticipated and for transporting rectal swabs (72). Modified Cary-Blair medium containing reduced agar (1.6 g/liter) appears to be the most suitable single transport medium for Campylobacter as well as other enteric pathogens. Specimens received in Cary-Blair medium should be stored at 4°C if processing is not performed immediately. Cary-Blair medium supplemented with laked sheep blood may be useful for prolonged storage of stool samples and recovery of C. jejuni (73). Thus, samples that have undergone prolonged transport without preservative or in the wrong preservative, formed stool samples, stool mixed with urine or with evidence of barium, and specimens received on a dry swab or lacking evidence of fecal material should not ordinarily be accepted for analysis.

sect2.title: Molecular Methods
sect2.para: Readers should refer to the package inserts of molecular detection systems for specimen collection, transport, and stability of fecal samples for testing, as recommended sample types may vary considerably.

sect1.title: Blood
sect1.para: Campylobacter species, primarily C. fetus, C. jejuni, and C. upsaliensis, have been isolated from blood; however, only a few studies have evaluated optimal conditions for isolating Campylobacter from blood culture systems. The Bactec (74) and Septi-Chek systems (both from Becton Dickinson [BD], Sparks, MD) support the growth of the common Campylobacter species (75, 76). The BacT/Alert system (bioMérieux, Inc.) also supports the growth of Campylobacter fetus (77). A recent retrospective report on Campylobacter isolated from the Bactec system showed a mean and median time to first report of a positive blood culture of 4 days (78). A review of campylobacter bacteremia was published by Louwen et al. (79).

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Clinical microbiologists do not normally consider performing Gram stain analysis of stool samples for diagnosis of bacterial gastroenteritis; however, this is a rapid and sensitive method for presumptive diagnosis ofCampylobacter enteritis. Campylobacter spp. are not easily visualized with the safranin counterstain commonly used in the Gram stain procedure and are somewhat thinner than other enteric Gram-negative bacteria; carbol-fuchsin or 0.1% aqueous basic fuchsin should be used as the counterstain for smears of stools or pure cultures (80). Because of their characteristic morphology, Campylobacter spp. may be detected by direct Gram stain examination of stools obtained from patients with acute enteritis, with sensitivity ranging from 66 to 94% and specificity above 95% (81). Phase-contrast and dark-field microscopy have also been used to directly detect motile campylobacters in fresh stool samples; however, the sensitivity of these approaches has not been studied widely, and these methods require significant microscopic expertise. A number of fecal markers have been used as indirect screening tools for inflammation associated with gastrointestinal infections. These markers include detection of fecal leukocytes, fecal lactoferrin, and fecal calprotectin. The performance characteristics of these tests do not appear to be sufficient to recommend these tests for routine screening for gastrointestinal infections (82).

sect1.title: Antigen Detection
sect1.para: Numerous commercially available fecal antigen detection systems forCampylobacter in stool samples are cleared by the FDA in the United States (83). A number of early studies suggested that Campylobacter species antigen immunoassays had good performance characteristics (84–86); however, these studies were not necessarily done using a prospective study design or examined only a small number of samples, or there was sample selection bias (i.e., enrichment for positive samples). Other studies have questioned the accuracy of fecal antigen assays (87–90). An extensive evaluation of several immunoassays, studying several thousand fecal samples, found that these assays were relatively insensitive and had poor positive predictive value and concluded that they should not be used as stand-alone diagnostic tests for gastrointestinal campylobacter infections (91). Other enzyme immunoassays available outside the United States have variable performance (92). It is recommended that positive immunoassay test results be confirmed by additional testing, by either culture or nucleic acid amplification testing, or as required by the manufacturer’s package insert.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques
sect1.para: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are now commonly being used to directly detectCampylobacter and other enteric pathogens in stool samples. Molecular approaches to detecting Campylobacter directly in fecal samples improve the time to detection, may allow identification to the species level, and may identify less common Campylobacter species often missed by conventional culture. Several laboratory-developed tests have been evaluated and use techniques, including real-time PCR, which target genes specific to C. jejuni and C. coli (and other species), and 16S rRNA gene sequencing (93–95).

Numerous commercial multiplex NAAT systems have been cleared by the FDA for detectingCampylobacter directly in fecal samples (83, 96–105). Kits use a variety of methods to simultaneously detect Campylobacter spp. and other targets, including Salmonella spp., Shigella spp., STEC, Vibrio spp., Yersinia enterocolitica, Plesiomonas shigelloides, Clostridioides difficile, intestinal protozoa, and viral agents, including norovirus and rotavirus. The assays vary regarding the type of platform, hands-on time, and workflow in the laboratory. Multiplex assays are highly sensitive compared with culture methods and are increasingly being used as the primary diagnostic tool for the diagnosis of campylobacter infections. Early studies evaluating multiplex assays showed high sensitivity (83 to 100%) and specificity (97 to 100%) for detecting Campylobacter (96–100). Recent evaluations confirm excellent performance of these multiplex assays (101–106).

There are some challenges when NAATs are used for detectingCampylobacter spp. in fecal samples. Verification of assay performance, especially when discordant results (e.g., NAAT positive but culture negative) are obtained, may be challenging for some laboratories. Acceptable specimen types may vary depending on the test platform and may require additional validation studies. There also is a need for additional studies on the appropriate time for repeat testing, if necessary, and the effect of antimicrobial therapy on test results. Finally, there may be significant costs associated with acquiring these newer test platforms.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: CommonCampylobacter species, such as C. jejuni, C. coli, and C. fetus, require a microaerobic atmosphere containing approximately 5% O2, 10% CO2, and 85% N2 for recovery from cultured clinical samples. Several manufacturers produce microaerobic gas generator packs or incubators; also, evacuation of an anaerobic jar and replacement with the approximate gas mixture may be used for routine cultures. The Anoxomat (Advanced Instruments, LLC, Norwood, MA) is a convenient automated system for the evacuation and gas replacement of jars used for generating different atmospheric conditions, including microaerobic conditions (107). The concentration of oxygen generated in candle jars is suboptimal and unacceptable for the isolation of Campylobacter spp., and so these jars should not be used for routine laboratory isolation procedures.

Some species ofCampylobacter, such as C. concisus, C. curvus, C. hyointestinalis, C. mucosalis, C. rectus, and C. sputorum, require increased hydrogen for primary isolation and growth (40, 108). These species are usually not recovered under conventional microaerobic conditions, since the amount of hydrogen generated in properly used commercial gas packs is <2%, and it is recommended that commercial suppliers develop a gas pack with appropriate concentrations of H2 for isolation of the hydrogen-requiring Campylobacter species. The use of anaerobic gas packs without catalyst to generate high H2 concentrations creates a laboratory safety hazard and should never be used for this purpose. A gas mixture of 10% CO2, 6 to 7% H2, and the balance N2 used in an evacuation-replacement jar is sufficient for isolating hydrogen-requiring species.

Media containing selective agents should be used for primary plating of stool samples (nonenriched) for reliable isolation ofC. jejuni/C. coli. A number of selective media using blood-containing and blood-free formulations are available from commercial sources. These include Campy-CVA (cefoperazone, vancomycin, and amphotericin) medium, charcoal cefoperazone deoxycholate agar (CCDA), and charcoal-based selective medium (CSM). CCDA and CSM have better performance characteristics than blood-containing media such as Butzler, Skirrow, and Campy BAP media (46, 109–113). Ideally, two types of media (e.g., CCDA and CVA) should be used to achieve optimal recovery of Campylobacter from fecal specimens, and this approach has been verified in several clinical studies (91, 114). Practically, most laboratories use a single selective medium for routine cultures, and it should be noted that this approach may be 10 to 15% less sensitive for recovery than using two media routinely. As a single medium, CCDA was found to be the most sensitive for detecting C. jejuni/C. coli when compared with Skirrow medium, agar containing cefoperazone, amphotericin, and teicoplanin, and filtration (40). If only a single medium is used, Campy-CVA, CCDA, or CSM is suggested. Chromogenic medium for isolation of Campylobacter has been described and has been evaluated in several studies with human fecal specimens (115, 116).

Charcoal-based medium containing cefoperazone, amphotericin, and teicoplanin is described as a selective medium for the primary isolation ofC. upsaliensis (117). Two studies, however, did not isolate C. upsaliensis from any stool samples by use of this medium (46, 118). C. upsaliensis may occasionally be recovered on some other selective media. C. upsaliensis can also be recovered by using the filtration method, and some strains may grow better in a hydrogen-enriched atmosphere (38, 119).

Species within the generaCampylobacter and Arcobacter have different optimal temperatures for growth. The choice of incubation temperature for routine stool cultures is critical in determining the spectrum of species that will be isolated. As a matter of convention, most laboratories use 42°C as the primary incubation temperature for Campylobacter. This temperature allows growth of C. jejuni and C. coli on selective media while inhibiting other fecal microbiota. C. upsaliensis also grows well at 42°C but usually is not recovered on selective media. C. fetus exhibits variable growth at this temperature and may not be recovered. Arcobacter species will generally not be recovered at 42°C.

In contrast, mostCampylobacter and Arcobacter species grow well at 37°C; however, some selective media, such as Skirrow medium, were devised for use at 42°C, and use of these media is not recommended for attempts to isolate Campylobacter species from stool samples using 37°C as the incubation temperature. CCDA and CSM, however, show good selective properties at 37°C (114). Plates should be incubated for a minimum of 72 h before being reported as negative. It has been reported that incubation of CCDA medium for 5 to 6 days increased the yield of C. jejuni and C. coli compared with 2 days of incubation (46).

IfCampylobacter infection is suspected at the time blood specimens are drawn, blood culture media should be subcultured after 24 to 48 h to a nonselective blood agar medium and plates incubated under microaerobic conditions at 37°C, preferably with increased hydrogen. This allows the isolation of thermophilic and nonthermophilic species. While commonly used blood culture systems should support the growth of Campylobacter and give appropriate signals if positive, it may be prudent to perform a blind subculture. Similarly, blood drawn in Isolator (Abbott Rapid Dx North America, Orlando, FL) tubes for bacterial culture should be cultured on a nonselective blood agar plate incubated under microaerobic conditions at 37°C if Campylobacter infection is suspected. If a curved, Gram-negative rod is observed upon Gram stain examination of a positive blood culture bottle, an aliquot should be cultured on a nonselective blood agar plate and incubated under microaerobic conditions at 37°C. An alternative stain, such as acridine orange, may also be useful for detecting campylobacters in blood culture bottles if the Gram stain is negative.

Optimal conditions for recovery ofArcobacter from clinical specimens have not been determined. Arcobacter spp. were first isolated on semisolid media designed to isolate Leptospira spp. Arcobacter species are aerotolerant and have been recovered on certain selective media, such as Campy-CVA (120), incubated under microaerobic conditions at 37°C and on nonselective media used in the filtration method (40). Selective media for isolation of Arcobacter spp. from human stool samples were evaluated by Houf and Stephan (62). Both selective plates and enrichment broth containing selective supplements with 5-fluorouracil, amphotericin B, cefoperazone, novobiocin, and trimethoprim showed good recovery of Arcobacter spp. (62).

sect1.title: Enrichment Cultures
sect1.para: Enrichment broths formulated to enhance the recovery ofCampylobacter from stool include Preston enrichment, Campy-thio, and Campylobacter enrichment broth (121–125). The clinical advantage and cost-effectiveness of using enrichment cultures as part of the routine stool culture setup have not been studied adequately; therefore, enrichment cultures are not recommended for routine use. However, enrichment cultures may be useful in reflex culture protocols to recover Campylobacter species from clinical specimens positive in molecular or other culture-independent diagnostic tests (CIDTs).

sect1.title: Filtration
sect1.para: Filtration techniques designed to isolateC. jejuni and C. coli as well as other Campylobacter species and Arcobacter spp. that are susceptible to antibiotics present in most selective media may be used to complement direct culture to selective plating media (40, 46, 61, 63). As only stool samples containing ~105 CFU/ml of Campylobacter will yield detectable organisms upon filtration, the filtration method should not be used as a replacement for direct culture, because it is not as sensitive as primary culture with selective media (108, 119).

The filtration method is based on the principle that campylobacters can pass through membrane filters (0.45-μm to 0.65-μm pore size) with relative ease (because the organisms are thin and highly motile), while other elements of the stool microbiota are retained during the short processing time. Several studies have confirmed that polycarbonate filters with a 0.65-μm pore size were superior to cellulose acetate membrane filters (108, 126), and these are recommended for use. Filtration is performed by placing a sterile 0.65-μm-pore-size polycarbonate filter onto the surface of an agar medium such as antibiotic-free CCDA, CSM, or blood-containing medium such as brucella blood agar. After dilution of approximately 1 g of stool in 10 ml of sterile saline or directly from transport medium, 10 to 15 drops of fecal suspension are placed on the filter, and the plate is incubated at 37°C for 60 min in ambient air (108). The filter is then removed, and the plate is incubated at 37°C under microaerobic conditions, with an atmosphere containing increased hydrogen (for the hydrogen-requiring species).

Because of the expense of including several types of media and the filtration method in the initial workup forCampylobacter, a practical approach is to use a single medium for isolation of thermophilic Campylobacter spp. in the workup of acute bacterial gastroenteritis, such as Campy-CVA, CCDA, or CSM incubated at 42°C. If the primary culture workup is unrevealing, and for patients with persistent diarrhea, cultures for non-C. jejuni/non-C. coli species may be appropriate. Additional stool samples should be plated on multiple selective media (e.g., CCDA or CVA), processed by the filtration method as well, and incubated at 37°C under microaerobic conditions with increased hydrogen.

sect1.title: Reflex Cultures
sect1.para: Although there are many advantages to using culture-independent methods for detectingCampylobacter species in fecal samples, a number of concerns arise from the adoption of these methods for routine laboratory testing (13). Laboratories should still maintain the capability of performing culture on CIDT-positive samples (or use a reference laboratory). Culturing is required to obtain antimicrobial susceptibility information for patient management and to submit isolates to local and state public health laboratories for outbreak monitoring, and it may be required by the CIDT manufacturer, as indicated in the package insert (127, 128).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: The identification ofCampylobacter species is difficult because of their complex and rapidly evolving taxonomy, fastidious growth requirements, and biochemical inertness (Table 2). These problems have resulted in a proliferation of phenotypic and genotypic methods for identifying members of this group (129).

sect1.title: Campylobacter spp. and Arcobacter spp.
sect1.para: Depending on the growth medium used,Campylobacter colonies may have different appearances. In general, Campylobacter spp. produce gray, flat, irregular, and spreading colonies. Spreading along the streak line is commonly seen, particularly on freshly prepared media. As the moisture content decreases, organisms may form round, convex, and glistening colonies with little spreading observed. Thus, proper storage of media to ensure sufficient moisture is important for optimal isolation and recognition of Campylobacter spp. Hemolysis on blood agar is not observed. Arcobacter colonies are morphologically similar to those of Campylobacter (2, 9).

The Gram stain appearance ofArcobacter may differ from that of typical Campylobacter spp. A. butzleri is only slightly curved, while A. cryaerophilus tends to be much more helical in appearance than Campylobacter spp. Commercial systems for identification of Campylobacter species were not found to be more accurate than conventional tests (130). Unfortunately, Campylobacter species are difficult to differentiate from Arcobacter species based on phenotypic tests. However, an aerotolerant species (i.e., exhibiting growth under aerobic conditions) that grows on MacConkey agar under microaerobic conditions could be presumptively identified as Arcobacter. The failure to grow on MacConkey agar, however, does not rule out Arcobacter species.

sect1.title: C. jejuni and C. coli
sect1.para: For initial analysis, a Gram stain examination of the colony should be performed along with an oxidase test. Oxidase-positive colonies exhibiting a characteristic Gram stain appearance (e.g., Gram-negative, curved or S-shaped rods) isolated from selective media incubated at 42°C under microaerobic conditions can be reliably reported asCampylobacter spp. The most common species, C. jejuni, is relatively easy to identify phenotypically; hydrolysis of sodium hippurate is the major test for distinguishing C. jejuni (and also C. jejuni subsp. doylei) from other Campylobacter species. Strains that are isolated on selective media that grow at 42°C, are oxidase positive, show characteristic microscopic morphology, and are positive for hippurate hydrolysis should be reported as C. jejuni, and for routine clinical purposes, no other tests need to be performed. Methods for the performance of hippurate hydrolysis are described elsewhere (131). Occasional strains of C. jejuni are hippurate hydrolysis negative, making them more difficult to identify. MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, or other gene-specific PCR assays (e.g., those for hipO) can also be used for definite identification (132–134). A number of other Campylobacter species may be hippurate hydrolysis positive but have not been reported to cause human infections, such as C. aviculae, C. avium, and C. taeniopygiae (Table 1).

With the exception of hippuricase activity, whichC. coli is lacking, C. coli and C. jejuni are similar biochemically (Table 2). Therefore, molecular or proteomic methods are needed to accurately identify C. coli and differentiate it from hippurate negative C. jejuni; most have proved both accurate and sensitive (135). MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry has been shown to accurately differentiate C. jejuni from C. coli (136). Further, direct identification using MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry appears to be quite accurate when performed using selective medium and colonies that are less than 48 h old; however, tests with older colonies may not be as accurate and may require subculture (133). If molecular testing is not available, strains isolated on selective media that grow at 42°C, are oxidase positive, show characteristic microscopic morphology, and are hippurate negative and indoxyl acetate positive should be reported as hippurate-negative C. jejuni/C. coli. Additionally, C. coli and Helicobacter pullorum have similar phenotypic profiles, which supports the use of molecular identification methods for these species (137). Susceptibility (inhibition) or resistance of Campylobacter spp. to nalidixic acid and cephalothin was historically used as an aid for species identification. However, with the increasing prevalence of fluoroquinolone resistance in these species, these disk identification assays should no longer be used for identification due to poor accuracy.

sect1.title: Species Other than C. jejuni or C. coli
sect1.para: For species other thanC. jejuni, phenotypic characterization alone does not allow definitive species-level identification; the use of additional molecular identification or MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry methods is recommended. Because many species of Campylobacter and Arcobacter are difficult to identify by phenotypic testing alone, tests for detection of species-specific sequences via PCR have been developed. The 16S and 23S rRNA genes are widely used for genus- and species-specific tests; PCR assays based on these targets have been described for different Campylobacter and Arcobacter species (129). Broad-range molecular identification schemes involving restriction fragment analysis of PCR-amplified regions of the 16S or 23S rRNA genes have also been described for identification of Campylobacter and Arcobacter species (138–140). Many other gene targets have been used in species-specific PCR assays, including gyrA, glyA, ceuE, asp, lpxA, and a GTPase gene (141). Subspecies identification by PCR within C. fetus and C. jejuni has also been described (141). While such PCR tests combine the advantages of being quick and easy to perform with low cost and high-throughput capability, being amenable to automation, it is important to validate PCR tests to fully determine their specificity and sensitivity before use.

Comparison of 16S rRNA gene sequences is also a useful tool for differentiation ofCampylobacter spp. from closely related taxa, such as Arcobacter and Helicobacter. However, it is important to note that species-level identification based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing is much more difficult, particularly for the common species of Campylobacter. At or above 97% identity, some groups of closely related species (such as C. jejuni, C. coli, and C. lari; C. upsaliensis and C. helveticus; and C. fetus, C. hyointestinalis, and C. lanienae) cannot be confidently distinguished from each other based on 16S rRNA gene sequences (142). Conversely, intraspecies 16S rRNA gene diversity is seen in other species, such as C. hyointestinalis (143).

MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry analysis may also be used to identify both common and uncommonCampylobacter species and is increasingly being used routinely in clinical laboratories for identification of common Campylobacter species. In a study of nearly 1,000 isolates, MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (MALDI Biotyper; Bruker Daltonics) had 99.4% accuracy for identifying C. jejuni and 100% accuracy for C. coli, C. fetus subsp. fetus, and C. lari as well as A. butzleri (134). Other studies also confirm the value of MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry identification of Campylobacter species (132, 144). Conditions for growth may need to be optimized for successful MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry analysis (133).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Typing systems forCampylobacter epidemiologic studies vary in complexity and in their ability to discriminate between strains. Common phenotypic methods that have been applied include biotyping, phage typing, and serotyping (145, 146). The HS Penner serotyping scheme detects 60 types of C. jejuni and C. coli. Initially thought to detect lipopolysaccharide antigenic determinants, the HS system has been shown to detect a Campylobacter capsular polysaccharide (147). Serotyping (HS) is performed in only a few reference laboratories worldwide because of the time and expense needed to maintain quality antisera. Conventional serotyping, while still in limited use, has been instrumental in identifying disease associations between Campylobacter and GBS (28). Other systems, such as biotyping and phage typing, do not have any practical applications for modern epidemiologic studies. More recently, multiplex PCR for capsular typing, which correlates quite well with conventional HS serotyping, has been developed (148–150).

The limitations of phenotypic subtyping methods and the rapid growth of molecular biology techniques in the 1990s led to the development of a range of molecular subtyping methods, such as restriction endonuclease analysis, ribotyping, PCR-based techniques, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis of macrorestricted chromosomal DNA (PFGE), and amplified fragment length polymorphism (145). The development of a rapid 1-day standardized PFGE protocol (151), which was used by participants of the PulseNet national surveillance network for foodborne pathogens (www.cdc.gov/pulsenet), facilitated the use of this approach for outbreak investigations of campylobacteriosis (20). However, interpretation of data can be difficult, since genomic rearrangements can lead to changes in PFGE profiles (152). Advances in DNA sequencing technology have provided a means to investigate strain variation at the nucleotide level and have led to the emergence of DNA sequencing-based subtyping systems, such as multilocus sequence typing (MLST) (153). MLST is useful for studies of the population structure and molecular epidemiology of C. jejuni, although commonly circulating sequence types can make recognition of outbreaks caused by these strains problematic (154, 155). Rapid advances in next-generation sequencing platforms made it possible to apply whole-genome sequence analysis in the context of molecular typing for C. jejuni. PulseNet now uses whole genome sequencing as the gold standard for typing Campylobacter (156). At present, no method alone is adequate for all applications, and a combination of methods, such as serotyping and molecular methods (MLST or whole-genome sequencing [WGS]), should be used for reliable determination of strain relatedness and for studying the epidemiology of Campylobacter infections (127). More-detailed reviews of molecular typing methods and their application for use in epidemiological studies of Campylobacter species have been published elsewhere (157, 158).

A number of typing methods have been applied to the study ofArcobacter species (58). An MLST system for Arcobacter spp. was reported several years ago (159). When a set of 374 isolates representing different species from different sources and geographic locations was used, no association of MLST type and location or source was observed.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serum immunoglobulin G (IgG), IgM, and IgA levels rise in response to infection, but serum and fecal IgA levels appear during the first few weeks of infection and then fall rapidly (160, 161). Serum antibody assays vary in both sensitivity and specificity for detecting Campylobacter infection, and test performance appears to be population dependent. Campylobacter antibody assays have been used to study patients with GBS and reactive arthritis (162). Samples from patients with Campylobacter infection may give false-positive Legionella antibody test results (163). Serologic testing appears to be useful for epidemiologic investigations (164) but is not recommended for routine diagnosis of campylobacter infection (165).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: C. jejuni and C. coli have variable susceptibilities to a variety of antimicrobial agents, including macrolides, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, chloramphenicol, and tetracycline. Macrolides are drugs of choice for treating C. jejuni and C. coli gastrointestinal infections, and for susceptible organisms, fluoroquinolones may also be used (166). Early therapy of susceptible Campylobacter infection with a macrolide or fluoroquinolone is effective in eliminating the organism from stool and may also reduce the duration of symptoms associated with infection (21).

C. jejuni and C. coli are generally susceptible to macrolides. Macrolide susceptibility has been remarkably preserved in C. jejuni, with 1.5 to 3.1% strains being found to be resistant yearly over the past decade (2012 to 2022) (167). Rates of resistance in C. coli are generally higher, with resistance rates of 5.3 to 17.3% during the same period.

Although fluoroquinolones have been effective in treatingCampylobacter infection, resistance is fairly high among U.S. C. jejuni isolates, with resistance rates ranging from 22.2 to 33.7% during the past decade. C. coli resistance rates are higher, ranging from 33.6 to 43.8% (167). Individuals with fluoroquinolone-resistant C. jejuni have been shown to have a longer duration of diarrhea, and thus, testing of isolates may be indicated if antimicrobial therapy is being considered (168, 169). C. jejuni and C. coli are resistant to some β-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins, and narrow-spectrum cephalosporins, but imipenem has good activity against Campylobacter.

Parenteral therapy is used to treat systemicC. fetus infections; drugs used include ampicillin, aminoglycosides, imipenem, and chloramphenicol, depending upon the type of infection. C. lari may be susceptible to fluoroquinolones, and resistance to macrolides is generally low (168). C. upsaliensis is generally susceptible to a variety of antimicrobial agents and shows low rates of resistance to macrolides and fluoroquinolones (168). A. butzleri and A. cryaerophilus have variable resistance to macrolides and fluoroquinolones (168).

Both the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (170) and European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (171) publish standards for susceptibility testing of Campylobacter spp. Disk diffusion (Kirby-Bauer method) may be performed for several drugs, including macrolides, fluoroquinolones, and tetracycline, with interpretive criteria published by CLSI and EUCAST. Susceptibility testing may also be performed using the Etest (bioMérieux, Inc.), which correlates well with other methods (172–174). Broth dilution is another convenient method for susceptibility testing with CLSI and EUCAST standards (170, 171).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Campylobacter species, most commonly C. jejuni and C. coli, should be sought in all diarrheic stools submitted to the laboratory, either by culturing or by using an FDA-cleared molecular assay for enteric pathogens. Except for epidemiological purposes, cultures of formed stools should not be performed. Detection of Campylobacter from a patient with acute diarrhea is usually significant, since the carrier rate in developed countries is quite low; however, in developing countries, isolation might be more difficult to interpret, especially in the presence of other enteric pathogens. In acute infection, there are usually a high number of organisms in the stool, but the quantity of organisms is not related to the severity of infection or indicative of a carrier state. Gram stain analysis of fecal samples to look for organisms with typical Campylobacter morphology is a highly sensitive and specific test that is underused; it may be performed for rapid preliminary diagnosis of Campylobacter infection. Other species, such as C. fetus subsp. fetus and C. upsaliensis, may be important causes of diarrhea and are not isolated on routine selective media. Special methods, including alternative incubation techniques, are required as described in this chapter and should be performed by special request. Oxidase-positive, curved, Gram-negative rods that are hippurate hydrolysis positive should be reported as C. jejuni without further workup. The importance of identifying other species depends on the clinical circumstance, but identification tests should always be performed with isolates from blood or other sterile sites, since this could influence antimicrobial therapy decisions. Because fluoroquinolone resistance is present in a significant proportion of C. jejuni isolates, fluoroquinolone susceptibility testing is suggested for patients who are receiving or being considered for therapy for gastroenteritis. Susceptibility testing should be performed with all isolates from sterile clinical sites.
